content: kate s mitts a friend of mine needed a pair of basic fingerless mitts to keep the chill of the air conditioner off her hands in the office she wanted something understated but not plain so i chose a super soft alpaca and row of a basic but interesting stitch pattern i made the cuff and the top of the mitt ribbed to allow a comfortable fit on many hand sizes supplies size 1 2 75mm crochet hook 150 yards of fingering weight yarn the mitts pictured used 70 yards each of inca tops 100% alpaca three ply yarn that i measured at 21wpi for my gauge swatch i got a two inch square from 15 double_crochet in 8 row stitches/abreviations used chain = chain stitch double_crochet = double_crochet fdc = foundation double_crochet see https //www interweave com/article/crochet/foundation-double-crochet-fdc/ for detailed ​ instructions on this stitch fpdc = front post double_crochet bpdc = back post double_crochet *mitts are worked in the round from the right side no turning as written the seam runs up the right side of each thumb toward the palm of the left hand and toward the back of the right hand i find this seam to be very subtle when worked in a solid color yarn with a nice halo also i asked my friend if she could find the seams and she said what seams if you desire instructions for moving the thumb gusset to the other side of the seam please let me know row 1 chain 3 fdc 49 yarn over and insert hook in chain of last fdc as you would to make another fdc then thru the 1st chain be sure not to twist the work yarn over and pull a loop through both chain finish the double_crochet stitch slip_stitch in 3rd chain counts as 50ch +50dc alternatively you could chain 50 slip_stitch in first chain ch3 double_crochet around to make 50ch + 50dc however the starting chain method is never quite as stretchy as the foundation chain method you should now have a loop that fits easily over the hand and is a little loose around the wrist if the loop is too tight you can add an even number of fdc to row 1 to obtain a size that does fit row 2-4 ch3 *fpdc bpdc repeat from * around slip_stitch in 3rd chain 50 double_crochet this completes the ribbed cuff the mitt should now fit more snuggly on the wrist if the cuff seems too tight you can reduce the number of stitches in row 1 by an even number to get a more comfortable size row 5-6 ch3 counts as double_crochet double_crochet in each double_crochet around slip_stitch in 3rd chain 50dc row 7 ch3 counts as double_crochet *skip next double_crochet double_crochet ch1 double_crochet in next double_crochet skip next double_crochet double_crochet in next double_crochet repeat from * around slip_stitch in 3rd chain row 8 ch3 counts as double_crochet double_crochet in first double_crochet double_crochet in next chain-1 space *skip next
